questions.text:
A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of fatigue and shortness of breath. The laboratory investigations are given below. Which of the following is used in the management of this condition?
  • Hemoglobin - Reduced
  • Serum ferritin - Raised
  • Serum iron - Raised
  • Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC) - Normal 
  • Hemoglobin electrophoresis - Normal
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, laboratory investigations reveal raised iron and ferritin with normal TIBC and hemoglobin electrophoresis point toward the diagnosis of sideroblastic anemia. Vitamin B6 is used in the management.

Raised iron levels rule out iron deficiency anemia and anemia of chronic disease. Normal hemoglobin electrophoresis rules out thalassemia. Hence the most probable diagnosis in this case is sideroblastic anemia.

Laboratory findings in sideroblastic anemia:

  • Peripheral smear: Hypochromic, microcytic (sometimes normocytic) anemia
  • Absolute values: MCV, and MCH are reduced and RDW is increased
  • Bone marrow: Ring sideroblasts are present.
  • Serum ferritin: Raised
  • Serum iron: Raised
  • TIBC: Normal
  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis: Normal

Iron studies 

  • Serum iron

The serum iron level represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin.
Normal range: 50–150 μg/dL

  • Ferritin

As free iron is toxic to cells it is stored in the form of ferritin. Apoferritin binds to free ferrous iron and stores it in a ferric state. 
Normal values- Adult Males: 100 μg/L and adult females: 30 μg/L

  • Transferrin saturation

Transferrin saturation is calculated with the following formula= serum iron x 100/TIBC
Normal range: 25–50%

  • Total iron binding capacity

Iron binding capacity is the capacity of transferrin to bind with iron. Iron binding capacity is of two types, TIBC and unsaturated iron-binding capacity (UIBC). When iron stores are depleted, the transferrin levels increase in the blood. As only one-third of transferrin is saturated with iron, the transferrin present in serum has an extra binding capacity (67%). This is unsaturated iron-binding capacity. TIBC is the total of serum iron and UIBC.

Normal range: 300–360 μg/dL.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presented to OPD for routine health checkup. Investigations were performed and are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 3 mg/dl
Direct bilirubin: 0.2 mg/dl
Indirect bilirubin: 2.8 mg/dl
AST: 40 U/L
ALT: 25 U/L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, isolated elevation of unconjugated (Indirect) bilirubin in an asymptomatic post-pubertal patient points towards the diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome have elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin. Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II has similar laboratory findings, however, it usually presents in the neonatal period.

Serum bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme-containing proteins. The normal serum total bilirubin levels are between 1-1.5 mg/dL. There are two types of bilirubin:

  • Conjugated (Direct) bilirubin: It is water-soluble and is excreted by the kidney. The normal upper limit is 0.3 mg/dl. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in the liver or biliary tract disease.
  • Unconjugated (Indirect) bilirubin: Unconjugated bilirubin always binds to albumin in the serum and is not filtered by the kidney. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in hemolytic anemias, Crigler-Najjar, and Gilbert’s syndromes. 

However, in the majority of liver diseases, both conjugated and unconjugated are elevated.

Liver enzymes

  • Aspartate aminotransferase (AST):
    Normal range: 7-56 U/L
    AST is found in multiple organs and is a less specific marker.
  • Alanine aminotransferase (ALT):
    Normal range: 0 to 35 U/L
     ALT is specifically found in the liver and is a more specific indicator of liver injury.

The AST: ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows:

AST: ALT Condition
<1 Chronic viral hepatitis, Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
>1 Cirrhosis
>2:1

Suggestive of alcoholic liver disease

Alcohol intake is associated with the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate, which in turn leads to decreased levels of ALT enzyme. So, AST>ALT.
>3:1 Highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease
  • Alkaline phosphatase and 5′-nucleotidase are the markers for cholestasis.

Serum albumin

Albumin is synthesized exclusively by hepatocytes. The level of albumin decreases in decreased liver function. However, the half-life of albumin is 18-20 days. Therefore it is not a good indicator of acute or mild hepatic dysfunction like viral hepatitis, drug-induced hepatotoxicity, etc. It mainly indicates chronic hepatic dysfunction.

Serum globulins

Serum globulins include γ globulin produced by B lymphocytes and α and β globulins produced primarily in hepatocytes. γ Globulins are increased in chronic liver diseases, such as chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis.

Coagulation factors

All the blood clotting factors are synthesized in the liver except factor VIII. In contrast to albumin, they have a very short half-life. Therefore, it can be helpful in diagnosing acute parenchymal diseases.

questions.text: You are examining the peripheral smear of a patient with anemia and see the following finding. What is responsible for the underlying change?
questions.solution:
The given peripheral smear shows Cabot rings which are nuclear remnants.

Cabot rings

Cabot rings are circular, blue, threadlike inclusions with dots. They are nuclear remnants. They are seen in hemolytic anemia, megaloblastic anemia, and post-splenectomy.

Other options

Option A: Acanthocytes are formed due to altered cell membrane lipids.

Option B: Ovalocytes (elliptocytes) are formed due to abnormal cytoskeleton.

Option D: Basophilic stippling is seen due to ribosomal precipitation.

Peripheral smear findings

Acanthocyte (spur cell)

Acanthocyte or spur cells are characterized by only a few spicules of varying size that project from the cell surface at irregular intervals. 

Conditions with acanthocytes include

  • Parenchymal liver disease
  • Abetalipoproteinemia
  • Post splenectomy/ hyposplenism.

Degmacytes or bite cells or blister cells

Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen. They are seen in G6PD deficiency and drug-induced oxidant hemolysis.

Dacrocytes or tear-drop cells

These are distorted drop-shaped RBCs. They are seen in myelofibrosis and myelophthisic anemia.

Echinocyte or Burr cells

They are red cells with short evenly spaced spicules formed due to altered cell membrane lipids. They are usually artifacts but can be seen in uremia, bleeding ulcers, and gastric carcinoma.

Schistocytes or helmet cells are fragmented RBCs that are seen in microangiopathic hemolytic anemias and mechanical valves.

Target cells

These RBCs have a target-like appearance and are often hypochromic. This is due to the increased redundancy of cell membranes. They are found in liver disease, post-splenectomy, thalassemia, hemoglobin C disease

Spherocytes:

These are spherical RBCS with a dense appearance and absence of central pallor. They are found in hereditary spherocytosis and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.

Sickle cells

Sickle cells are bipolar, spiculated forms, pointed at both ends. They are formed due to aggregation of HbS. They are seen in sickle cell anemia.

Howell-Jolly bodies

These are nuclear remnants within red cells that are usually small, single, discrete, and basophilic in appearance. They are seen in hemolytic anemia, megaloblastic anemia, and post-splenectomy.

Basophilic stippling

Blue granules of various sizes are dispersed throughout the cytoplasm of the red cell, they represent ribosomal precipitates. They are seen in lead poisoning and thalassemia.

Pappenheimer bodies

These are small dense basophilic granules. They are seen in sideroblastic anemia and post-splenectomy.

questions.text: An elderly man presents to the OPD with decreased urine output and facial puffiness. His estimated glomerular filtration rate was 42 mL/min/1.73 sq.m. What is the stage of his chronic kidney disease according to the KDIGO classification?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a GFR of 42 ml/min/1.73 m² indicates that the patient is in stage 3b according to KDIGO classification. 

Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD):

Stage GFR
Stage 1 > 90 ml/min/1.73 m²  
Stage 2 60 to 89 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 3a 45 to 59 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 3b 30 to 44 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 4 15 to 29 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 5 (end-stage renal disease) < 15 ml/min/1.73 m²

Renal function tests

A) GFR

GFR is the rate in millilitres per minute at which substances in plasma are filtered through the glomerulus. The normal GFR for an adult male is 90 to 120 mL/min

The characteristics of an ideal marker of GFR are as follows: 

  • It should appear endogenously in the plasma at a constant rate
  • It should be freely filtered at the glomerulus
  • It can be neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubule
  • It should not undergo extrarenal elimination.

Inulin is the most commonly used marker for GFR estimation.

B) Serum creatinine

Creatinine is the by-product of creatine phosphate in muscle. It is eliminated from the body by the kidney.
Normal range: 0.6 to 1.2 mg/dl

It is increased in 

  • Acute or chronic renal failure
  • ↑ Protein intake
  • High muscle mass

It is decreased in 

  • Low muscle mass
  • Pregnancy

C) Blood urea nitrogen

Urea is produced in the liver as the end product of protein metabolism and the urea cycle. 
Normal range: 5 to 20 mg/dl

Urea is elevated

    • Reduced GFR(Acute/chronic renal failure)
    • High protein diet
    • Upper GI bleeding
    • Dehydration

Urea is decreased in starvation, low-protein diet, and severe liver disease.

The ratio of BUN to creatinine can be useful to differentiate pre-renal from renal causes. In pre-renal disease, the ratio is close to 20:1, while in renal disease, it is closer to 10:1. However, Upper GI bleeding can be associated with a very high BUN to creatinine ratio (sometimes >30:1).

D) Uric acid

It is a catabolic metabolite of purines.

It is increased in

  • Acute renal failure
  • Tumor lysis syndrome
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

questions.text: A patient presents to OPD with complaints of vesicles and plaques over the trunk. On examination, the vesicles were characteristically arranged in an annular pattern around the lesion. An immunofluorescence study of his lesions revealed the following picture. Which of the following antigens is targeted in this disease?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of vesicles is arranged in an annular fashion around the lesions called string‐of‐pearls, crown of jewels, or cluster of jewels sign with immunofluorescence showing linear pattern is suggestive of linear IgA disease. The antigen targetted in this disease is BP180 aka BPAG2.

Direct immunofluorescence

Linear fluorescence pattern as shown below occurs due to deposits along the dermo-epidermal junctions (DEJ). This is seen in the following conditions:

  • Due to linear IgG deposits in Bullous Pemphigoid, and Epidermolysis bullosa acquisita.
  • Due to linear deposits of IgA at DEJ in Linear IgA dermatosis.

Focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips are seen in Dermatitis herpetiformis.

Fish-net appearance on immunofluorescence is seen in pemphigus vulgaris. It is due to anti-desmoglein IgG antibodies deposited on the desmosomes (Dsg3, Dsg1), which are present inter-cellularly.

questions.text: The blood levels of various cardiac biomarkers are measured in a patient following a myocardial infarction. This is represented in the given graph. Which biomarker does the blue curve depict?
questions.solution:
The blue curve in the graph represents myoglobin as it is the first marker to be elevated post-myocardial infarction. Myoglobin rises within 1-4 hours, reaches a peak at around 12 hours, and returns back to normal levels at around 24 hours.

Cardiac biomarkers - 

Troponin T/I:

  • These are the proteins that mediate calcium-mediated contraction of the cardiac and skeletal muscles.
  • They are highly specific for MI.
  • Troponins will remain elevated longer than creatine kinase (CK), for up to 14 days.

Creatine kinase (CK):

  • It is less sensitive and specific than troponins
  • It can be elevated in other conditions such as hypothyroidism, chronic renal failure, and severe exercise. 

Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • Normally, LDH2>LDH1; but, in MI, LDH1>LDH2. This is called flipping of the LDH ratio.
  • Current recommendations suggest that LDH no longer has a role in the diagnosis of MI.

Myoglobin:

  • One of the earliest enzymes to increase after MI.
  • Not specific to cardiac muscle and can be elevated to any form of injury to skeletal muscle.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure. Renal biopsy revealed crescents in most of the glomeruli. Immunofluorescence finding is shown in the image below. Which of the following is most commonly targetted in this disease?

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a patient with recurrent hemoptysis and renal failure, along with crescents on renal biopsy and linear immunofluorescence (IF) staining. These findings are characteristic of Goodpasture syndrome, in which antibodies are targeted against the α3 chain of collagen type IV.

In Goodpasture's syndrome, autoantibodies are directed against the α3 chain of type IV collagen found in the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes. This leads to a type II hypersensitivity reaction, which causes pulmonary hemorrhage, leading to hemoptysis, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which leads to renal failure.

Renal immunofluorescence studies: In rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) type I and Goodpasture syndrome, immunofluorescence reveals a linear pattern (as shown below), which is a classic feature of anti–glomerular basement membrane disease (anti-GBM) disease. 

Below are various immunofluorescence patterns observed. The image shows negative immunofluorescence, indicative of minimal change disease. There are no Ig or complement deposits.

Granular appearance on immunofluorescence microscopy is shown below, which is seen in:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: Immunofluorescent stain demonstrates discrete, coarsely granular deposits of complement protein C3 and IgG corresponding to “humps”.
  • Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis Type II: It is immune-complex mediated and shows granular deposits on the immunofluorescent stain.
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) Type I: Immunofluorescence shows IgG and C3 and early complement components(C1q and C4) deposited in a granular pattern.
  • Membranous nephropathy: Immunofluorescence microscopy demonstrates that the granular deposits contain both immunoglobulins and complement.

Lupus nephritis: Immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as a full-house effect.

IgA nephropathy: Immunofluorescence microscopy shows IgA deposition in the mesangium.

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis type 2 (MPGN type 2) or dense-deposit disease: Immunofluorescence shows C3 deposition in irregular granular or linear foci in the basement membranes on either side but not within the dense deposits.

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis: Immunofluorescence microscopy shows IgM and C3 deposition in the sclerotic areas and/or in the mesangium.

Option C: A Mutation in the α5 chain of collagen type IV is seen in Alport syndrome.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of easy fatigability, weight loss, and an evening rise in temperature. Investigations reveal pancytopenia. The bone marrow aspirate of a patient is shown in the image given below. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). This subtype of disease is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the presence of Auer rods on bone marrow aspirates and t(15:17) on cytogenic studies points towards the diagnosis of AML-M3. DIC is most commonly associated with AML-M3.

Peripheral smear (WBC):

1) Acute myeloid leukemia

Acute myeloid leukemia is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations. This leads to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow resulting in marrow failure and complications related to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.

  • Bone marrow/peripheral smear shows a large, uniform population of cells (myeloblasts) with prominent nucleoli (yellow arrow). It shows the presence of primary cytoplasmic granules
  • Auer rods: Needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies(black arrow) particularly seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia (AML M3) with t(15;17).

 

2) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) 

ALL arises from immature B (pre-B) or T (pre-T) cells called lymphoblasts. Immunohistochemistry for terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase (TdT) is positive in pre-B and pre-T lymphoblasts. Peripheral smear shows lymphoblasts that have condensed chromatin, less conspicuous nucleoli, and scant basophilic cytoplasm which lacks granules as shown below.

3) Chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL)

CLL is associated with the deletions of 13q, 11q, 17q, and trisomy 12q. Lymph nodes are diffusely effaced by small lymphocytes with proliferation centers. The peripheral smear shows small round lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm and smudge cells as seen below.

4) Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML)

CML is characterized by the presence of a Philadelphia chromosome resulting from reciprocal translocation t(9;22) forming the BCR-ABL fusion gene. They have hypercellular marrow due to a massively increased number of maturing granulocytic precursors. The image below shows peripheral smear findings of CML with neutrophils, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and band cells.

Lab findings HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc
1 +   - +  -  IgM
2  - -  +/- +/- IgM
3 +  -  +   -  IgG
4 + -  -  +  IgG
questions.solution:
The window phase of hepatitis B is indicated by lab finding 2.
 
The window period is a phase where even though hepatitis infection is present, HBsAg is non-reactive. Diagnosis is based on the presence of IgM Anti HBc

questions.text:
You are the intern posted in the emergency department. You came across an ABG report given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this change?

pH: 7.50
PaCO2: 28 mm of Hg
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given ABG report shows increased blood arterial pH(Normal range: 7.35-7.45), decreased PaCO2(Normal: 35 - 45 mmHg) and normal HCO3 levels(Normal: 22-28 mEq/L) indicating respiratory alkalosis.The most likely cause of respiratory alkalosis is panic disorder, which causes hyperventilation.

Metabolic disorders

Conditions Features Etiology
Metabolic acidosis

There is decreased blood arterial pH because of an increase in endogenous acid production (Example: Diabetic ketoacidosis, increased lactate in sepsis), loss of HCO3- (Example: diarrhoea), or low excretion of net acid by kidneys (Example: chronic kidney disease). Respiratory compensation (alveolar hyperventilation) occurs causing a decrease in PaCO2.

High anionic metabolic acidosis

  • Methanol
  • Uremia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Propylene glycol
  • Iron tablets
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Salicylates (Late)

Normal anionic gap metabolic acidosis

  • Hyperalimentation
  • Addison's disease
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Diarrhea
  • Acetazolamide
  • Spironolactone
  • Saline infusion
Metabolic alkalosis

There is increased blood arterial pH, as a result of a net gain of HCO3- or a loss of nonvolatile acid from the extracellular fluid. Compensatory alveolar hypoventilation occurs and causes an increase in PaCO2. 

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Removal of gastric secretions- vomiting or nasogastric suction
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
    • Villous adenoma
    • Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin
  • Renal loss
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Posthypercapnic states
    • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome

Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume):

  • Loop or thiazide-type diuretics
  • Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis
  • Gastric losses in achlorhydria

Miscellaneous:

  • Bartter's syndrome
  • Gitelman's syndrome
Respiratory acidosis

There is decreased blood arterial pH as a result of an increase in PaCO2 following alveolar hypoventilation.
  • Central: Stroke, infection
  • Airway: Obstruction, Asthma
  • Lung Parenchyma: Emphysema, Pneumoconiosis, Bronchitis
  • Neuromuscular: Muscular dystrophies, Myasthenia
  • Obesity
  • Hypoventilation
Respiratory alkalosis

There is an increase in blood arterial pH due to a decrease in PaCO2 due to alveolar hyperventilation.

Hyperventilation

  • Anxiety/panic attack
  • Hypoxemia( eg: High altitude)
  • Salicylates (Early)
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Tumor

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

A patient presented with a passage of cola-colored urine and abdominal pain. Flow cytometry of the blood of a patient revealed the following findings? Which of the following can be used in the management?

Data of the Patient in Red
Data of Normal individual in Black
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the history of the passage of cola-colored urine and abdominal pain with the flow cytogram showing a population of red blood cells deficient in both CD55 and CD59 is suggestive of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Eculizumab can be used in the management of PNH.

Есսlizumаb is a monoclonal antibody that binds to complement protein C5, preventing cleavage into C5a and C5b. Blocking the formation of C5b inhibits the subsequent formation of MAC.

Other options

Option B: Emicizumab is used in the management of hemophilia A.

Option C: Rituximab is used in the management of CLL

Option D: Trastuzumab is used in the management of breast cancer.

Flow cytometry 

Flow cytometry is used to identify cellular antigens expressed by tumors that arise from blood-forming tissues. These include B-cell and T-cell lymphomas and leukemias as well as myeloid neoplasms. An advantage of flow cytometry over immunohistochemistry is that multiple antigens are assessed simultaneously.

Interpretation of results:

  • Quadrant 1- Cells marked in green: -VE for A antigen, +VE for B antigen
  • Quadrant 2- Cells marked in purple: -VE for both the antigens.
  • Quadrant 3- Cells marked in yellow: +VE for both the antigens.
  • Quadrant 4- Cells marked in red: +VE for A antigen, -VE for B antigen
